title: Part A(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how a change in the availability of a specific resource can affect the carrying capacity of a species, such as any of the following:

· If the availability of a specific resource (food, water, habitat) increases, then the carrying capacity can increase.

title: Part B(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one negative effect of clear-cutting forested areas, such as any of the following:

· Forests contain trees that sequester carbon. The cutting and burning of trees releases carbon dioxide and contributes to climate change.

· Forests contain trees that absorb pollutants. The cutting down of trees reduces the absorption of pollutants.

· Clear-cut areas have higher rates of soil erosion compared to forested areas.

· Clear-cut areas have higher soil and stream temperatures than forested areas. This can impact nutrient uptake in plants, plant growth, and fish habitats.

· Clear-cut areas have increased flooding compared to forested areas.

· Forests provide a habitat for a variety of species; clear cutting areas will reduce available habitat and contribute to loss of biodiversity.

title: Part B(ii)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

Note: No points given for a response that describes creating or expanding forest preserves as a mitigation strategy.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one mitigation strategy that humans can employ to reduce the negative impact of human population growth on forests, such any of the following:

· Practice sustainable forestry where trees that are harvested are replaced with seedlings that can grow into new trees

· Manage a forested area to extract some resources while still maintaining core biomass so the forest can serve an ecological role in ecosystem.

· Use alternative fuels (renewable or nonrenewable) rather than burning biomass.

· Build up, not out, and construct or maintain high-density dwellings or neighborhoods to reduce overall land used for housing developments.

· Include forested areas as part of housing development plans to maintain a portion of land as forest ecosystem.

· Practice sustainable agriculture and food production (vertical farming, ocean farming, etc.) to reduce need to clear forested land for farming.

· Establish ecotourism in a forested area.

title: Part C(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain one likely social or economic cause for the decreasing crude birth rate illustrated in stage 3, other than that fewer children were born, such as any of the following:

· Transition from an agricultural country to an industrialized country makes more children a financial burden rather than the financial benefit of additional workers on farm.

· Rise in relative affluence of the country can affect the status of women, decrease reliance on child labor, or shift social structure.

· Expansion of women's status and access to education, economic opportunity, or political power in the country increases the age of first pregnancy or increases career advancement for women, decreasing the number of children born per woman.

· Increased access to contraception enables family planning and decreases fertility rates.

· Increased average age at marriage increases the average age of a woman at first birth, decreasing the overall number of children per woman.

· Increased access to medical intervention, vaccines, prenatal care etc. leads to a decrease in mortality rates and improves life expectancy, which influences demographic trends.
